title: Bipartisan Deal Struck on Jan. 6 Capitol Riot Probe
sub_head: Top congressional Republicans didn’t immediately endorse proposal to establish independent commission; House vote expected as early as next week
body:
WASHINGTON—The leaders of the House committee on Homeland Security have struck a bipartisan deal to create an independent commission investigating the Jan. 6 assault on the U.S. Capitol, but top congressional Republicans didn’t immediately endorse the proposal.
The chairman of the House Committee on Homeland Security, Bennie G. Thompson (D., Miss.), said Friday that he had reached an agreement with the panel’s top-ranking Republican, Rep. John Katko (R., N.Y.), to introduce legislation to form the commission, with a vote expected as early as next week.
“Inaction—or just moving on—is simply not an option,” Mr. Thompson said of the agreement, reached after months of negotiations.
Mr. Katko said the commission “is about facts, not partisan politics.”
The New York lawmaker was one of 10 Republicans who voted to impeach former President Donald Trump for inciting insurrection against the U.S. government on Jan. 6, when a pro-Trump mob stormed the Capitol to try to stop lawmakers from ratifying President Biden’s electoral college victory. Mr. Trump was acquitted by the Senate in February.
